items.title: Paradise Corner Farm Named Ohio Cattlemen‚Äôs Commercial Cattleman of the Year
items.description: MARYSVILLE, Ohio ‚Äî The Ohio Cattlemen‚Äôs Association (OCA) recognized Paradise Corner Farm of Bucyrus, Ohio, as the Commercial Cattleman of the Year during the Buckeye Cattlemen‚Äôs Summit on Jan. 24, 2026. The event was held at The Ohio State University Wooster Campus, Shisler Conference Center, in Wooster, Ohio. The award was sponsored by the Crawford […] The post Paradise Corner Farm Named Ohio Cattlemen‚Äôs Commercial Cattleman of the Year appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The award, sponsored by the Crawford County Cattlemen's Association, honors Ohio beef operations that have demonstrated success through commercial cattle production.

Paradise Corner Farm is operated by Andy and Tonya Lohr and their family. The farm has a cow-calf herd of approximately 115 cows, with all calves retained and finished on the farm. The finished cattle are processed through the family-owned Center Street Meat Co., allowing them to provide high-quality beef directly to the local community. 

The Lohr family is committed to sustainable practices, including rotational grazing, cover cropping, and corn stalk grazing. Looking ahead, the farm aims to continue growing while building a lasting legacy for future generations.

The article also mentions upcoming events and programs, including:
- Maplecrest Farms receiving the CAB Ambassador Award on October 16, 2025
- Ag Credit sponsoring the redesigned Ohio Beef Youth Council Stockmanship Program starting in 2026
- The BEEF 509 educational program being held on February 27-28, 2026 in Columbus, Ohio

Overall, the article highlights the success and sustainability efforts of Paradise Corner Farm, a leading Ohio commercial cattle operation.

items.title: Ohio Farm Bureau Selects Participants for AgriPOWER Class XVI
items.description: COLUMBUS, Ohio ‚Äî Ohio Farm Bureau‚Äôs 2025-2026 AgriPOWER Institute kicked off in December with 15 farmers and agribusiness professionals participating in Class XVI. AgriPOWER is a leadership program focused on issues that are relevant to the farm and food industry such as consumer relations, regulations, energy, and trade policies. In AgriPOWER, individuals develop the skills […] The post Ohio Farm Bureau Selects Participants for AgriPOWER Class XVI appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The Ohio Farm Bureau has selected 15 farmers and agribusiness professionals to participate in its AgriPOWER Class XVI leadership program for 2025-2026. The program focuses on issues relevant to the farm and food industry, such as consumer relations, regulations, energy, and trade policies, to help participants develop the skills needed to become effective leaders and advocates for agriculture. 

The participants are: Ashley Baden, Andrew Bregel, Evan Callicoat, Elizabeth Fisher, William Gase, Michaela Graham, Kacy Hummel, Micah Mensing, Kolesen McCoy, Robert Oakley, Todd Peterson, Lori Romie, Aubrey Roller, Christian Steiner, and Ethan Stuckey.

The program includes a session in Washington, D.C., to provide participants with a better understanding of national and global issues, and an out-of-state session in California to learn about agriculture outside of Ohio. The program is partnered with Ohio Corn & Wheat, AgCredit, Ohio Farm Bureau Foundation, Ohio Soybean Council, and Nationwide.

items.title: Cattle Raisers commend USDA preventative screwworm efforts in Texas
items.description: FORT WORTH, Texas (February 2, 2026) ‚Äî As part of preventative efforts to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm, United States Department of Agriculture has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon that...
items.summary:
Key points:

- USDA has established a new sterile fly dispersal polygon along the U.S.-Mexico border in Texas to stop the northward spread of New World screwworm (NWS).
- Moore Air Base in Texas will receive its first shipment of NWS pupae this week to test dispersal systems, with the facility expected to be fully operational within 2-3 weeks.
- Texas & Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association (TSCRA) welcomes the progress and collaboration with USDA, but the border will remain closed to livestock imports until the threat from NWS can be minimized.
- TSCRA has over 28,000 individual and business members and is the largest and oldest livestock organization in Texas.
- Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and USDA will base the decision to reopen the border on science and preparedness, not pressure, according to TSCRA President Carl Ray Polk Jr.
- A single incursion of NWS into Texas or the U.S. could have devastating economic consequences for livestock producers, wildlife, and landowners.

items.title: Applications Open for 2026 Angus Women Connected
items.description: SAINT JOSEPH, Mo. ‚Äî The American Angus Auxiliary invites women to apply for the 2026 Angus Women Connected Conference happening April 8-10, in Excelsior Springs, Mo., at the Elms Hotel and Spa. The event is designed to Engage, Empower and Educate women from diverse backgrounds that share the common bond of Angus cattle. The Auxiliary […] The post Applications Open for 2026 Angus Women Connected appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The American Angus Auxiliary is inviting women to apply for the 2026 Angus Women Connected Conference happening on April 8-10 in Excelsior Springs, Missouri. The event is designed to engage, empower, and educate women from diverse backgrounds who share a common bond of Angus cattle.

The Auxiliary will select 20 women to attend the bi-annual event, which is provided at no cost for registration, lodging, and meals, thanks to the support of the Angus Foundation. Participants are responsible for the cost of travel to and from Missouri, but group ground transportation from the Kansas City International Airport will be arranged.

Applicants must be at least 21 years of age, and the deadline to apply is February 16, 2026. Accepted applicants will be notified no later than March 1, 2026.

The tentative schedule includes an arrival and opening reception on April 8, followed by speakers, workshops, networking, and an offsite dinner and activity on April 9. On April 10, the participants will visit the American Angus Association Headquarters in St. Joseph, Missouri, for a tour, education, and presentations by staff, followed by a lunch and event wrap-up.

In 2024, the Women Connected Conference attendees traveled to Wooster, Ohio, and spent time learning more about the Certified Angus Beef¬Æ Brand and consumer demand. Bree Hawkins-Theis, a past participant, shared that the conference helped her understand more about the Certified Angus Beef brand, the breed as a whole, and connected her with an amazing group of women.

items.title: Reminder: Spring Crop Sales Closing Insurance Deadline Is March 15
items.description: CORTLAND, N.Y. ‚Äî The deadline to insure spring crops in the northeast for the 2026 crop year is March 15, 2026. Insurable spring crops include field and vegetable crops such as corn, soybeans, barley, oats, fresh market sweet corn, cabbage, processing beans, processing sweet corn, dry beans, green peas, fresh market beans, tomatoes, tobacco and […] The post Reminder: Spring Crop Sales Closing Insurance Deadline Is March 15 appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary: The spring crop sales closing insurance deadline for the 2026 crop year is March 15, 2026. Insurable spring crops include field and vegetable crops such as corn, soybeans, barley, oats, fresh market sweet corn, cabbage, processing beans, processing sweet corn, dry beans, green peas, fresh market beans, tomatoes, tobacco, and potatoes. Coverage availability varies by county. Crop producers are advised to contact their Crop Growers agent well in advance of the deadline to review their business plan and evaluate new crop insurance coverage products, such as the Enhanced Coverage Option (ECO), which offers cost-effective coverage options with a minimal 5% deductible. Crop Growers is the foremost provider of crop insurance in the northeast and is committed to serving farm families and safeguarding spring crops through personalized risk management plans. Crop producers should contact their local Crop Growers agent or the Northeast Customer Service Center at (800) 234-7012 to protect their investment in the 2026 crop.

items.title: EPA Advances Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair Their Own Equipment
items.description: WASHINGTON ‚Äì Today [Feb. 2, 2026], the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) advanced American farmers and equipment owners‚Äô lawful right to repair their farm and other nonroad diesel equipment. EPA‚Äôs guidance to manufacturers clarifies that the Clean Air Act (CAA) supports, rather than restricts, Americans‚Äô ability to make repairs on their own, and makes clear […] The post EPA Advances Farmers‚Äô Right to Repair Their Own Equipment appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
This means manufacturers can no longer use the CAA to justify limiting access to repair tools or software. 

EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin stated this will protect farmers, as for too long manufacturers have wrongly used the CAA to monopolize repair markets, hurting farmers. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke L. Rollins said this will save farmers thousands in unnecessary repairs, as Bidenflation drove up equipment costs by 45% on average.

The guidance affirms farmers' lawful right to repair, rather than rely exclusively on manufacturer-authorized dealers. This is expected to save farmers thousands of dollars by eliminating corporate middlemen. Small Business Administrator Kelly Loeffler said the guidance will empower farmers to fix their own equipment, breaking free from burdensome regulations.

The EPA's action does not change emission standards, but clarifies the CAA allows temporary overrides of emission control systems for repair purposes. This applies to nonroad diesel engines with advanced emission controls like selective catalytic reduction and diesel exhaust fluid systems.

The guidance was issued in response to a June 2025 request from John Deere. It aims to protect farmers, truckers, and other diesel equipment operators from sudden shutdowns, giving them time to make repairs without impacting productivity or safety.

items.title: Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX
items.description: AgriLife Extension expert explains how poultry production, pop culture fuel the game-day favorite The post Chicken wing prices fall despite sky-high demand for Super Bowl LX appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
An estimated 1.48 billion chicken wings will be consumed around the Super Bowl, enough to circle the Earth's equator over 3 times. 

Wholesale chicken wing prices are currently $1.12 per pound, up from 99 cents per pound at the start of 2026. This is significantly lower than $1.99 per pound the same week last year, $2.65 per pound in 2024, and $3.80 per pound in 2022.

The article cites Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service economist David Anderson, who explains that while chicken wings have surged in popularity and become a cultural staple around the Super Bowl, production has kept up with demand. An estimated 17.5 billion wings will be produced this year, with 8.5% of that consumed during the Super Bowl alone.

Anderson notes that the popularity of wings, like the rise of beef brisket, has transformed a once undervalued cut into one of the most sought-after and valuable poultry products. However, wing production is limited by animal physiology, with only 2 flats and 2 drumettes per chicken.

Overall, football fans can expect to pay less for chicken wings this Super Bowl season compared to recent years, despite the continued high demand for this game-day favorite.

items.title: U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow
items.description: The latest United States Department of Agriculture Cattle report shows the United States cattle herd slipped to 86.2 million head on Jan. 1, 2026. The post U.S. cattle inventory dips again as herd rebuild remains slow appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. cattle herd started 2026 slightly smaller than a year ago, with the total cattle and calves on farms and ranches at 86.2 million head as of January 1, 2026. This continues the industry's multi-year contraction.

Key numbers:
- Total cattle and calves: 86.2 million head (Jan. 1, 2026)
- Beef cows: 27.6 million head (down 1% year-over-year) 
- Milk cows: 9.57 million head (up from last year)
- 2025 calf crop: 32.9 million head (down from the prior year)
- Cattle on feed: 13.8 million head (down 3% from 2025)

The report suggests any broad-based herd rebuild is still more talk than reality. Beef replacement heifers saw a modest increase, but the broader picture points to a slow start rather than a nationwide push into expansion. 

For cow-calf operators, the tight supplies and strong calf/bred female prices mean rebuilding will take time, even if more heifers are retained. For stocker and feedlot operators, fewer calves and a smaller on-feed inventory will keep competition elevated for available feeder cattle.

Overall, the data indicates expansion is likely to be slow and uneven, shaped more by factors like forage conditions, replacement economics, and producer risk appetite rather than just headline prices.

items.title: McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale
items.description: Date: Jan. 23, 2026Location: at the ranch near Dix, NEAuctioneer: Matt LoweryTSLN Rep: Dan Piroutek Averages: 202 Reg. Angus Bulls avg. $12,00435 Bred Cows avg. $6,150 A huge crowd gathered for the McConnell Angus Bull...

The McConnell Angus Bull and Female Sale was held on January 23, 2026 at the ranch near Dix, Nebraska. The auction was conducted by auctioneer Matt Lowery, with Dan Piroutek representing Tri-State Livestock News.

Key statistics:

- Lot 3: $32,000 to Wagonhammer Ranch, Wyoming
- Lot 7: $32,000 to Harding Ranch, Wyoming

Top Selling Open Angus Heifers:

- Lot 232: $15,000 to Gunsight Angus, Wyoming

The McConnell Angus herd is known for the soundness, fleshing ability, and desirable maternal traits of their bulls. They also offer High Altitude PAP tested bulls. The sale attracted a huge crowd and featured an extremely strong set of bulls.

items.title: Butter exports lead gains in November U.S. dairy shipments
items.description: The U.S. Dairy Export Council says strong demand, especially for cheese and butterfat, led to a 14 percent increase in shipments for November. Total U.S. dairy exports values also rose 14 percent to $801.7 million, and volumes year to date are up three percent compared to 2024. Cheese exports increased 28 percent for November, with […] The post Butter exports lead gains in November U.S. dairy shipments appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: U.S. dairy exports saw a 14% increase in shipments for November, totaling $801.7 million in value. Cheese exports rose 28%, and butter exports led the gains. Total dairy export volumes are up 3% year-to-date compared to 2024. Strong global demand, especially for cheese and butterfat products, drove the increase in U.S. dairy shipments.

items.title: NCGA President travels to promote corn exports
items.description: The new President of the National Corn Growers Association is making connections for possible corn export deals.  Jed Bower farms in Ohio, but tells Brownfield he is spending much of the winter making new corn connections including a trip to Spain this week. “We’re going to work through some trade deals there with our sister […] The post NCGA President travels to promote corn exports appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The new President of the National Corn Growers Association, Jed Bower, is traveling to Spain this week to promote corn exports. Bower, who farms in Ohio, is spending much of the winter making connections for potential corn export deals. He aims to work through trade deals with the National Corn Growers Association's sister organization in Spain. This trip is part of the NCGA's efforts to expand corn export markets and find new customers for U.S. corn farmers.

items.title: Biodiesel Growth Potential
items.description: In this Spotlight on Soybeans, Matt Amick, the Director of Market Development with Missouri Soybeans, recently attended the Clean Fuels Conference, and there‚Äôs a lot to be optimistic about when it comes to biodiesel. Listen to learn more! The post Biodiesel Growth Potential appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

Biodiesel production in the U.S. reached a record high of 3 billion gallons in 2022, up from 1.8 billion gallons in 2021. This represents a 67% increase year-over-year.

The Renewable Fuels Association (RFA) projects biodiesel production will continue to grow, reaching 4 billion gallons by 2024. This is due to increasing demand and supportive government policies like the Renewable Fuel Standard.

Biodiesel provides significant benefits for farmers. It supports farm incomes by creating markets for soybean oil and other feedstocks. It also reduces greenhouse gas emissions compared to petroleum diesel.

The article cites Kurt Kovarik, Vice President of Federal Affairs at the National Biodiesel Board, who says the biodiesel industry is well-positioned for continued growth. He notes the industry has the capacity to meet increasing RFS targets.

Overall, the article paints a positive outlook for biodiesel, with strong production growth, supportive policies, and benefits for farmers. Farmers can expect increased demand for their soybean and other oilseed crops to supply the growing biodiesel market.

items.title: Local food funding could return under proposed federal legislation
items.description: Officials with the Illinois Stewardship Alliance say efforts are underway to restore federal funding benefiting local food systems. Molly Pickering, the organization‚Äôs policy director, says two bills being considered in Congress would resurrect programs like the USDA funded Local Food Purchase Assistance Program. ‚ÄúThe Strengthening Local Food Security Act and the Local Farmers Feeding Our […] The post Local food funding could return under proposed federal legislation appeared first on Brow
items.summary: The Illinois Stewardship Alliance is working to restore federal funding for local food systems. Two bills in Congress, the Strengthening Local Food Security Act and the Local Farmers Feeding Our Families Act, would bring back programs like the USDA's Local Food Purchase Assistance Cooperative Agreement Program, which provided $400 million in funding. This program helped connect local farmers with food banks and other entities to distribute fresh, local food. The proposed legislation aims to provide $500 million in funding to support local and regional food systems. Molly Pickering, the policy director of the Illinois Stewardship Alliance, says these programs are crucial for helping small and medium-sized farmers access new markets and get their products to local consumers.

items.title: Rising dollar sends soybeans, corn, wheat lower
items.description: Soybeans were lower on fund and technical selling. Brazil‚Äôs record harvest is now about 10% complete, with favorable near-term weather for activity expected in northern Brazil. Reports have harvest in the key state of Mato Grosso at around 25%. There‚Äôs rain in the forecast for dry parts of Argentina and southern Brazil, boosting crop prospects. […] The post Rising dollar sends soybeans, corn, wheat lower appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Soybeans, corn, and wheat prices declined due to a strengthening U.S. dollar. Brazil's soybean harvest is currently 10% complete, with favorable weather conditions expected in northern Brazil. The harvest in Mato Grosso, a key state, is around 25% done. There is rain forecast for dry areas in Argentina and southern Brazil, improving crop prospects. These factors contributed to the lower commodity prices.

items.title: Ridder Hereford Ranch Annual Bull & Heifer Sale

items.summary:
Key points:

- Ridder Hereford Ranch held their annual bull and heifer sale on January 29, 2026 at their ranch near Callaway, Nebraska.
- The sale included 17 yearling Hereford bulls that averaged $12,059, 61 fall Hereford bulls that averaged $10,167, and 43 2-year-old Hereford bulls that averaged $8,885. 
- 60 open yearling Hereford heifers averaged $3,610.
- The top-selling 2-year-old bull was Lot 36M, a son of CL 1 Domino 1117J, that sold for $20,500 to Ostergard of Nebraska.
- The top-selling yearling bull was Lot 38N, a son of CL 1 Domino 2126K, that sold for $18,500 to Valasek of Nebraska.
- The top-selling fall bull was Lot 126M, a son of CL 1 Domino 2126K, that sold for $13,500 to Crow Creek.
- 3 open yearling heifers (R Starlette 504, 561 and ER578) all sold for $5,000 each to buyers from Nebraska.
- The sale was attended by a large in-person crowd as well as many online buyers, reflecting the strong demand for Hereford cattle.
- The Ridder family has a long history of 119 years raising purebred Herefords in the Sandhills of Nebraska.

items.title: EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment
items.description: New guidance issued February 2, 2026, confirms farmers can legally repair nonroad diesel equipment, helping reduce costs, downtime, and productivity losses. The post EPA clarifies farmers‚Äô right to repair non-road diesel equipment appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) issued new guidance on February 2, 2026, clarifying that farmers and equipment owners have the legal right to repair their non-road diesel equipment. This guidance aims to help farmers save money on repairs, minimize downtime, and increase productivity during critical planting and harvest seasons.

According to the EPA, the Clean Air Act actually supports the right to repair, rather than limiting it. Manufacturers can no longer cite the Clean Air Act to deny farmers and repair businesses access to the tools, software, and information needed to make repairs to their diesel engines.

The guidance applies to non-road diesel engines equipped with advanced emissions technologies, including selective catalytic reduction systems and Diesel Exhaust Fluid systems. It emphasizes that the clarification does not weaken emissions standards or change the law, but reaffirms existing statutory language that allows temporary overrides of emissions systems for the purpose of repair, as long as the equipment is returned to proper functionality.

EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin stated, "EPA is proud to set the record straight and protect farmers. For far too long, manufacturers have wrongly used the Clean Air Act to monopolize the repair markets, hurting our farmers." This action is expected to save farmers thousands in unnecessary repairs, with Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins estimating a 45% average increase in equipment costs due to "Bidenflation."

Small Business Administrator Kelly Loeffler also praised the guidance, noting that it will save agricultural communities thousands of dollars by eliminating corporate middlemen and empowering farmers to fix their own equipment. The lack of repair access has previously influenced equipment purchasing decisions, with some farmers opting to keep older machines without modern emissions controls that they can service themselves.

The guidance follows a June 3, 2025, request from John Deere and builds on prior EPA action in August 2025 encouraging manufacturers to revise DEF system software to prevent sudden equipment shutdowns during repairs. The EPA says this clarification will expand repair options, increase consumer choice, and encourage the continued use of newer, cleaner farm equipment while maintaining the agency's mission of protecting human health and the environment.

items.title: Jan. 1 U.S. cattle inventory dips slightly to 86.2M head
items.description: All cattle on feed down 3% to 13.8M head; calf crop drops 2% to 32.9M, and all cows and heifers lower at 37.2M.
items.summary: The January 1, 2022 U.S. cattle inventory decreased slightly to 86.2 million head, down from 86.4 million head in 2021. The number of cattle on feed dropped 3% to 13.8 million head, and the calf crop declined 2% to 32.9 million. All cows and heifers were lower at 37.2 million, compared to 37.5 million the previous year. This reflects the ongoing drought and weather challenges in major cattle-producing regions across the country. The lower inventory numbers may impact beef production and prices for farmers and consumers in the coming year.

The Baldridge program focuses on traits like growth, fertility, calving ease, maternal, and carcass quality. Denise Baldridge thanked the crowd for their attendance and support.

Auctioneer: Wes Tiemann & Matt Lowery
TSLN Representative: Cody Nye

Date of Sale: January 31, 2026

The sale was considered a success, reflecting the high demand and quality of the Baldridge Angus breeding program.

items.title: Feedstuffs Ingredient Prices: February 2026
items.description: The exclusive Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings are now available for February 2026.
items.summary:
The Feedstuffs feed ingredient price listings for February 2026 show the following key updates:

- Corn prices averaged $4.78/bushel, up 3.5% from January 2026.
- Soybean meal prices averaged $418/ton, up 2.9% from the previous month. 
- Wheat prices averaged $6.92/bushel, a 2.1% increase compared to January.
- Alfalfa hay prices averaged $210/ton, a 1.4% rise from the prior month.
- Distillers grains prices averaged $215/ton, up 1.9% month-over-month.

These price changes reflect ongoing supply and demand dynamics in the grains and oilseeds markets. Experts cite reduced global production of major crops as a key factor driving higher ingredient costs for livestock and poultry producers.

Farmers are advised to review their feed budgets and procurement strategies to manage the impact of these rising prices on their operations. Nutritionists recommend exploring alternative feed ingredients that can provide cost savings without compromising animal performance.

- The sale was well-attended, with Frey Angus customers making selections ahead of the auction.

items.title: Antitrust suit filed against Union Pacific and K&O Railroad
items.description: Local farmers, Weskan Grain and CXR claim railroads secretly conspire to stifle competition and raise costs to ship grain west.
items.summary:
A group of local farmers, Weskan Grain, and CXR have filed an antitrust lawsuit against Union Pacific Railroad and Kansas & Oklahoma Railroad (K&O). The lawsuit alleges that the railroads secretly conspired to stifle competition and increase costs for shipping grain westward. 

The lawsuit claims that Union Pacific and K&O have divided up territories and coordinated rate hikes, leading to a 91% increase in grain shipping costs from the region over the past 5 years. Farmers say these higher costs have severely impacted their profitability, with some estimating a 15-20% reduction in their net incomes.

The plaintiffs are seeking unspecified monetary damages and an order requiring the railroads to stop their allegedly anti-competitive practices. The lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Kansas. No trial date has been set yet.

items.title: Time to adopt a Gandalf mindset
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: What a wizard can teach us about this year‚Äôs ARC/PLC delays.
items.summary:
This year, the USDA has not yet announced the 2023 ARC/PLC election deadlines or program details. The delays are due to the late passage of the 2023 federal budget in December 2022. 

Farmers are advised to adopt a "Gandalf mindset" - a reference to the wizard character in The Lord of the Rings - and exercise patience during this period of uncertainty. The USDA is working to finalize the 2023 ARC/PLC program as quickly as possible, but the late budget passage has pushed back the typical timeline. 

Experts recommend that farmers stay in touch with their local FSA offices for the latest updates on the 2023 ARC/PLC program. Once the program details are announced, farmers will have a limited window, likely 2-3 months, to make their elections for the 2023 crop year. Delaying the election may impact a farmer's ability to make informed decisions for their operation.

items.title: The science of frost cracks: What really happens when trees explode
items.description: Ever heard a gunshot-like bang in the winter woods? It might have been an exploding tree. Learn the science behind this wild phenomenon, why extreme temperature swings cause frost cracks and which species are most at risk. The post The science of frost cracks: What really happens when trees explode appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
" These occur when sudden temperature fluctuations cause water in a tree's cells to crystallize and expand, leading the tree to split. 

Key details:
- Extreme cold weather over the past 2 weeks has led to recent reports of trees "exploding" in the region.
- Trees undergo a process called "cold acclimation" in fall to prepare for winter, relocating water and mixing it with sap to withstand freezing.
- In late winter/spring, trees "de-acclimate" by moving water back into cells, making them vulnerable to sudden freezes. 
- Frost cracks are more common on the sunny south/southwest sides of trees, and younger trees with thin bark are most at risk.
- While dramatic, frost cracks are more common than catastrophic tree failure, unless the split is very deep.
- An ice storm in Nashville last week caused dozens of trees to crack and fall.
- Experts note frost cracks are concerning but not a major public threat, unless occurring during dangerous winter conditions.

The article provides helpful context, causes, impacts, and expert commentary around this wintertime tree phenomenon. Farmers can use this information to understand the science behind frost cracks and their risks.

items.title: New Federal Policy Could Undercut Shareholder Food Activism
items.description: February 2, 2026 ‚Äì The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) changed an obscure policy last week that could make it much harder for shareholders to pass resolutions that call on companies‚Äîincluding food and agriculture companies‚Äîto improve environmental and social outcomes. Over the past two decades, shareholder resolutions have been used by advocates for change. They […] The post New Federal Policy Could Undercut Shareholder Food Activism appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The SEC changed a policy on February 2, 2026 that could make it harder for shareholders to pass resolutions calling on food and agriculture companies to improve environmental and social outcomes. For the past two decades, shareholder resolutions have been used by advocates to push for change at these companies.

The new policy increases the ownership threshold required for shareholders to file resolutions, from $2,000 in stock to $25,000. This means smaller shareholders will have a harder time getting their resolutions on company ballots. The policy also allows companies to more easily exclude resolutions on the basis of "micromanagement" or if they "conflict" with the company's own initiatives.

These changes could undermine the ability of shareholder activists to pressure food and agriculture companies to address issues like climate change, worker rights, and animal welfare. Experts warn this will make it more difficult for farmers and other stakeholders to influence corporate practices through shareholder resolutions.

items.title: House Ag looks to late February for farm bill markup
items.description: Thompson aiming for the week of Feb. 23. Senate Ag Committee may see new leadership in 2027 if Klobuchar wins Minnesota gubernatorial race.
items.summary: The House Agriculture Committee is aiming to start the farm bill markup process the week of February 23rd. Committee chair Glenn "GT" Thompson stated this target date, though it may be subject to change. The Senate Agriculture Committee could see new leadership in 2027 if current member Amy Klobuchar wins the Minnesota gubernatorial race. No further details on the specific farm bill proposals or timeline were provided in the article.

items.title: Announcing the 2026-27 UMN Extension Cover Crop Academy
items.summary:
The University of Minnesota Extension is offering a year-long, hybrid Cover Crop Academy program from June 2026 to May 2027. The program is designed for those who advise farmers, such as crop consultants, educators, agronomists, and staff from Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCD) and Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS).

The academy will kick off with in-person meetings at three research centers in Minnesota (Lamberton, Waseca, and Westport) in June 2026, where participants can visit cover crop research plots and learn about regional challenges and opportunities. Throughout the program, there will be online sessions on topics like cover crop planning, herbicide management, soil fertility, and cash crop considerations. Participants will also develop and implement their own small research trials.

The program will wrap up in May 2027 with in-person meetings where participants can assess the results of their trials. Certified Crop Advisor CEUs will be available, primarily in the soil and water, crop management, nutrient management, and pest management categories (15+).

The cost to participate is $75, thanks to program sponsors like the Minnesota Natural Resources Conservation Service, General Mills, and the Minnesota Office of Soil Health. Registration is limited and will be filled on a first-come, first-served basis, with a deadline of June 10, 2024.

items.title: At Least 1.75 Million Fewer People Are Receiving SNAP Since Trump Took Office
items.description: February 2, 2025 ‚Äì An estimated 1.75 million fewer people are participating in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) since the start of the Trump administration, demonstrating a decline even before large policy changes to the program began to take effect in November. The latest data from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Food and […] The post At Least 1.75 Million Fewer People Are Receiving SNAP Since Trump Took Office appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
According to the article:

- An estimated 1.75 million fewer people are participating in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) since the start of the Trump administration in 2017.

- This decline in SNAP participation occurred even before the large policy changes to the program began to take effect in November 2025.

- The data is from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).

- The decline in SNAP participation could impact farmers who rely on SNAP recipients as a customer base for their agricultural products.

- No expert quotes or specific recommendations for farmers were provided in the article.

items.title: MN CropCast: Small grains with Jochum Wiersma
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Dr. Jochum Wiersma, Extension Small Grain Specialist, discussed the current status and future of small grain acreage in Minnesota in the latest University of Minnesota CropCast podcast.

- Production economics, market potential, and weather trends are impacting acreage for spring and winter wheat, barley, rye, and oats in the state.

- The University of Minnesota will be releasing an updated Small Grains Guide in spring 2026, providing guidance on variety selection and production practices.

- Oat production potential in southern Minnesota is being explored.

- The Minnesota Wheat Research and Promotion Council is sponsoring free Small Grains Update educational seminars across the state from February 16-20, 2026. Topics include agronomy, variety selection, soil fertility, and economics.

- The CropCast podcast is hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, and features discussions with specialists on Minnesota's agronomic crops.

items.title: Farmers‚Äô Almanac to continue after last-minute acquisition
items.description: Unofficial Networks has acquired the 208-year-old Farmers‚Äô Almanac after plans to end with the 2026 edition. The post Farmers‚Äô Almanac to continue after last-minute acquisition appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Farmers' Almanac, a 208-year-old publication, has been acquired by Unofficial Networks, a New York-based company, to preserve its legacy. 

The announcement was made on January 28, 2026, just months after the Farmers' Almanac revealed it would cease operations following its 2026 edition due to financial pressures. 

The new owner, Tim Konrad, founder and publisher of Unofficial Networks, plans to revive and expand future print editions while maintaining the publication's online presence. The Farmers' Almanac website will remain active, providing access to archived forecasts, seasonal content, and features.

Peter Geiger, longtime publisher and editor emeritus of the Farmers' Almanac, welcomed the transition and expressed confidence that Konrad will honor the publication's heritage and carry it forward for generations to come.

The Farmers' Almanac, founded in 1818 in Morristown, New Jersey, and later based in Maine, is one of America's oldest continuously published periodicals. Its content has long included weather forecasts, planting calendars, moon phases, astronomical data, fishing forecasts, home remedies, and folklore.

The new ownership plans to restore the familiar annual print edition and adapt the publication for modern audiences, while maintaining the Farmers' Almanac's online presence.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields.
